Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support work on fundamental aspects of particle packing problems. There are many open questions that will be pursued. Can sphere packings with a diversity of density and disorder be identified in d-dimensional Euclidean space? What are the densest packings of spheres in dimension greater than three? What are the densest packings of nonspherical objects in two and three dimensions? Can random packings ever fill space more densely than ordered packings (implying disordered or ``glassy" ground states)? For non-tiling nonspherical particles, can an upper bound on the maximal density be derived that is always strictly less than unity? Specifically, the following seven general areas will be explored: (1) jammed sphere packings with anomalously low densities; (2) identification of growing length scales in the approach to the glass transition; (3) dense spheres packings in three-dimensional space with a size distribution; (4) jammed disordered polyhedron packings; (5) maximally dense packings of nonspherical particles; (6) maximally dense sphere packings in high dimensions; and (7) studies of jamming on the unit sphere in various space dimensions. Among other activities, this award will be used to support the research of graduate students seeking their Ph.D. degrees.

Packing problems, such as how densely solid objects fill space, have fascinated people since the dawn of civilization, and continue to intrigue scientists because of their connection to a host of problems that arise in the physical sciences, mathematics, engineering and biology. While optimal packing problems are intimately related to solid states of condensed matter, disordered sphere packings have been employed to model the glassy state of matter and granular media. Dense packings of nonspherical particles in low dimensions are relevant to problems in materials science and biology. Sphere packings in high dimensions is of importance in communications theory. Pure mathematicians have a longstanding interest in packing problems. This is a multidisciplinary project that links the applied mathematics, statistical and condensed-matter physics, materials science, engineering, biology, communications, and pure mathematics communities. Important scientific advances and practical outcomes that could potentially emerge from the proposed research include a deeper understanding of the nature of low-temperature states of matter (e.g., crystal ground states, the glass transition and the mysterious occurrence of disordered ground states), granular media, mechanically stable low-weight network solids, identification of new alloy crystal structures and new high-pressure phases of matter, and insights concerning the manner in which biological cells or organelles pack.

POR.DRECONTENT:
General outcomes and finding of this project concerned the generation and characterization of dense ordered and disordered packings of spheres and nonspherical shapes across various Euclidean space dimensions. Organizing principles to construct dense packings of nonspherical hard particles of general shape in three dimensions. We determined the equilibrium phase behavior and MRJ state of truncated tetrahedra were formulated. The densest-know packings and phase diagram of hard convex lens-shaped particles in three dimensions. We found the densest known packings of a large class of non-circular shaped particles in two dimensions were determined.  It was shown that the avian photoreceptor patterns (for detection of color) represent a disordered hyperuniform solution to a multiscale packing problem. It was demonstrated that length scales, based on the hyperuniformity concept, diverge on approach to a prototypical model of a glass. The density at which the viscosity of a suspension of bimodal spherical particles is linked to the maximally random jammed (MRJ) density was obtained. It was found that three-dimensional MRJ binary sphere packings can attain an anomalously large range of packing fractions for relatively small particle-size disparities. The highest fidelity MRJ sphere packings in three dimensions were analyzed and it was demonstrated that a ``critical-slowing down" phenomenon on approach to jamming. MRJ sphere packings under confinement were investigated. The existence of isostatic, maximally random jammed monodisperse hard-disk packings was demonstrated and a corresponding predictive theory for such packings and their generalizations was formulated.  Hyperuniformity in two-dimensional, disordered, jammed packings of soft spheres was studied. The Torquato-Jiao algorithm was applied to obtain the densest known lattice sphere packings for dimensions 2 through 19 and studied ensembles of isostatic lattice sphere packings. The effective diffusion coefficients of random packings of polydisperse hard spheres were estimated. Disordered hyperspheres across dimensions were characterized, including MRJ packings as well as random sequential addition of hard hyperspheres at saturation. Continuum percolation of overlapping hyperspheres and oriented hypercubes as well as randomly oriented overlapping nonspherical hyperparticles, all of which can be mapped to corresponding equilibrium hard-particle problems, were examined. The notion of a ``perfect glass" was introduced and investigated.

This was a highly multidisciplinary project that linked statistical and condensed-matter physics, materials science, engineering, applied and pure mathematics, and biology. Unifying these different perspectives and goals offered great rewards to the scientific community in general. The outcome of our work that MRJ binary sphere packings can achieve anomalously high packing densities and are entropically favored has led to several patent filings.
